awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Smart Tracking Systems for Safe and Smooth Interactions Between Scooters and Road Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) grant will study smart tracking systems on scooters for ensuring safe and smooth interaction with other vehicles and pedestrians on the road. The smart system consists of inexpensive sensors, active sensing based estimation algorithms, and deep learning based robust image processing to enable trajectory tracking of all nearby vehicles on the road. If the danger of a scooter-vehicle collision is detected, an audio-visual alert is automatically provided to the car driver to make them aware of the presence of the scooter. The system also monitors the scooter rider’s behavior, provides real-time feedback to improve rider compliance with traffic signals and sidewalk rules, and documents the information as a part of the rider’s safety record. The key attractive features of the system are that it is inexpensive (< $500), is immediately useful on today’s roads without requiring the vehicles on the road to be equipped with additional technology, and is potentially commercializable. The project contributes to the society by improving safety of micro-transportation systems, and broadens participation in computing via undergraduate research activities and promoting significant cross-disciplinary collaboration between faculty in engineering, computer science and human factors.

The project will conduct research to develop two novel vehicle tracking technologies. The two technologies, one based on use of a low-cost single-beam laser sensor and another based on a low-cost low-density Lidar sensor, can have applications in protecting vulnerable transportation users such as bicyclists, motorcyclists, scooter riders, users in developing countries and also in other cyber-physical systems such as indoor robots. The computer vision system will handle rain, snow and low lighting which pose a major challenge by corrupting normal image data. New robust deep-learning-based recognition techniques will be developed that can effectively deal with corrupted image data sets. This will be achieved by novel nonlinear modeling of the low-complexity structures in both the clean data and in the image corruption using deep learning and allowing for mixed corruption types, varying severity and possible corruptions in the training data itself. To ensure human-in-the-loop robustness, the project utilizes human subject studies to evaluate the effectiveness of a variety of audio and visual mechanisms for alerting the motorist and the scooter rider, including innovations such as providing visual cues of biological motion on the scooter to improve localization of the scooter by motorists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project conducted research on techniques to protect an e-scooter rider from crashes while riding on regular local roads.  In particular, the project developed methods to track the trajectories of all nearby vehicles on the road, detect the potential danger of an errant driver colliding with the e-scooter and provide audio-visual alerts to the errant driver so as to make him/her aware of the presence of the e-scooter. This was based on the use of low-cost sensors entirely located on the e-scooter.  The project also explored the importance of highlighting biological motion of the e-scooter rider so as to improve visual detection by other road users for night riding and also explored the detection of potholes on the road for purposes of alerting the e-scooter rider.

The following are highlights of the most important findings:

1)    The project developed a number of new methods to design nonlinear observers (nonlinear estimation algorithms) to track the trajectories of nearby vehicles on the road.  The advantage of the new observer design methods is that they provide guaranteed convergence properties.

2)    The project showed that the relative motion models in literature that are currently used to track moving vehicles are incorrect when the distance sensors are mounted on a turning platform such as an e-scooter or a vehicle.  The models are only correct when the sensors are mounted on a straight travelling vehicle. New relative motion models that work on turning vehicle platforms were developed.

3)    The project developed a method to estimate time-to-collision or time-to-intrusion using a single monocular camera.  This enables detection of collision danger using an ultra-low-cost (< $50) sensor.  Unlike previous methods, the new method does not use stereo cameras, does not use additional distance sensors and also does not make assumptions regarding the standard size of the vehicle being tracked.  The University of Minnesota has approved the filing of a patent application on this invention and is helping the research team explore the possibility of licensing this technology to commercial partners.

4)    The project has developed general image preprocessing algorithms for robust object recognition by using novel blind image deblurring and universal image denoiser techniques.  These algorithms were motivated by the need to correctly recognize stop sign and traffic light detection in the presence of snow, rain and other low-visibility conditions.

5)    A study on the role of biological motion showed that a moving human runner was detected better and more frequently in noisy conditions than the e-scooter rider or a static object. Using technologies to highlight biological motion on a e-scooter could improve visual detection by other vehicle drivers on the road, especially for night-time riding on the e-scooter.

Major outreach activities (broader impact activities) in the project included the establishment of an Mechanical Engineering (ME) Ambassadors Program to promote interaction of undergraduate ME students with middle school students so as to promote interest in STEM education, participation in organizing an annual CAV Career Pathways summer camp for high school students, the launching of a nonlinear control systems class that includes significant results on observer design from this research project, and preparation of a nonlinear control design and state estimation textbook that is scheduled to be published in summer 2025.
